captions.text:
Good morning Hank, it's Wednesday. I'm in
Venice and I'm really sick, but I don't want

to talk about either of those things. I want
to talk about the Evil Baby Orphanage and
our first president, George Washington.

Right, so, Hank, as I'm sure you recall, a
few years ago Nerdfighters came up with the

idea that instead of, like, going back in
a time machine and KILLING evil people when

they're babies, we could go back and kidnap
them and take them to the Evil Baby Orphanage
where, you know, we could rehabilitate them.

Hank, it's obviously a fantastic idea, aside
from the small problem of, you know, time

travel being... quite challenging. But here's
my question, Hank: how do you decide who is
a good candidate for the Evil Baby Orphanage?

Take, for example, George Washington. Terrible
Evil Baby Orphanage candidate, right? Like,

he fought the British in the War for Independence,
he was a huge part of the American constitution,

represented democracy, wooden teeth, six-foot-eight,
weight a frickin' ton, all that stuff. He

was also inarguably REALLY good at being the
American president.

But, Hank, what if our nearly universal assumption
that the American Revolution was a good thing

is wrong? Like, let's say we kidnap George
Washington as a baby and take him to the Evil

Baby Orphanage, "how, if at all, does that
change history?" turns out to be a pretty

interesting question. Let's assume - although
I think this is a bit dubious - that somehow

removing George Washington from history causes
us to lose and/or not fight the Revolutionary

War. It probably takes the United States at
least 70 more years to achieve its independence,

like, let's assume that we're following the
"Canada Model", but we still eventually end

up with a representative democracy, and if
we're following the "Canada Model", some excellent
beer.

Furthermore, as pointed out in M.T. Anderson's
brilliant novel The Astonishing Life of Octavian

Nothing, the revolutionary war was decidedly
a bad thing for the people who most needed

the protection of a government: the slaves.
And Hank, it's almost certain that slavery

would have ended earlier in America if we
had just remained a British colony. Furthermore,

Hank, it's not totally unreasonable to assume
that, with slavery ending in the early 19th

century at some point, we might have avoided
the Civil War, which was the bloodiest conflict

in United States history, resulting in 600,000
dead people.

But it doesn't stop there, Hank, because we
know that one of the key factors in the French

Revolution was that France bankrupted itself
helping us fight our revolution. Now, Hank,

I'm not saying that George Washington - who,
by the way, was a slave-owner - is responsible

for a century of slavery or 600,000 dead people.
I'm just saying that, as usual, the truth
resists simplicity.

So, Hank, here's my non-rhetorical question
for the day: how do we know who's a good candidate

for the Evil Baby Orphanage, given the complexity
of history? And more importantly, how do we

know that we ourselves are not living lives
that could result in us going to the Evil
Baby Orphanage?

Let's continue the conversation in comments
and in Your Pants. Hank, I'll see you on Friday.

title: The Evil Baby Orphanage Returns...for George Washington?

comments.text:
I know that i'm very late to the party, but here's where I stand on the 
evil baby issue: In order to be admited to the Evil Baby Orphanage, a baby 
must meet the following criteria.
1. Is the baby direstly responsible for at least one death (outside of was, 
self defense, or lawful execution)?
2. Has the baby directly and undoubtedly had a negative impact on 
history(Causing cruel, needless, or incredibly numerous deaths, poverty, 
famine disease,rape, theft or distructionof inportant and valuable objects 
etc..)?
3. Did the baby do these things purposfuly and of thier own will?
4. Has the baby had no positive  impact on history?

If the answer to all these is yes, the baby is a canditate for the Evil 
Baby Orphanage.﻿
comments.author: Coco and Zee

comments.text:
yeah, since this comment I have been thinking the same thing.  I don't 
think any baby in the orphanage meets all these criteria. who does?
comments.author: Coco and Zee

no radar and no penicillin and no... So hitler helped the world and should 
not go to the evil baby orphanage. and what constitutes a positive impact?

comments.text:
I'm not sure if there is one way to ensure one does not belong in the Evil 
Baby Orphanage, especially since we cannot predict the future and history

we do not have to be sent there.﻿

comments.text: John and Hank in the EBO is a great twist for a fanfic﻿
comments.author: Robby Barnard

comments.text:
Lives saved over lives taken. If it's greater than 1, they're free. If it's 
less than 1, orphanage.﻿
comments.author: Alanna R.

comments.text:
You mean how do we find reliable people for those high positions who will 
not be selfish and fight for the greater good? Good question, I'm not even 
sure if we've solved that in yet in the political system. I mean there is 
no system for selecting such a personal trait, you just have to listen to 
their prepared speeches and hope you pick the right candidate. Is there a 
psychological method to determine a suited leader? That could be useful. As 
far as I know Platon said that philosophes should rule, since they had the 
knowledge (could also have been Sokrates)
comments.author: Loubna Ait

comments.text:
+Loubna Ait Oh, ok. I see what you mean. So, for example, they couldn't 
have a criminal record. But something occurred to me. If Hitler hadn't 
existed, there's a possibility that I wouldn't have been born. So if I was 
a judge, maybe I would vote to keep Hitler, so that I'd be born. Of course, 
I myself wouldn't do that, and I think most people wouldn't if it saved so 
many lives, but if they were on the fence about putting the evil baby in 
the EBO, they might choose not to if it meant them never being born. Or 
maybe a really selfish person would vote to keep Hitler if it meant they 
wouldn't be born otherwise. So how do we fix this?
comments.author: Alanna R.

comments.text:
Why do we need judges for the judges? We could develope a sytem to 
determine if candidates are suited and vote. The only judges we would need 
are those who sort the historical babys in to nica and naughty like a 
timetraveling santa. (Doctor if you exist, this is the opportuinity to step 
in! *joking* *half-joking*)
comments.author: Loubna Ait

comments.text:
Well, if we did it that way, who would pick the judges? You would need a 
judge for the judges, and we would have the same problem.
comments.author: Alanna R.

comments.text:
Sure, but with a bit bad luck there could be a big part of "evil" people in 
the court. The politic systems we already have brought out some people who 
have some radical and terrible opinions (in my opinion; I don't mean to 
offend anyone). And what if we end up with a d*ck (or MULTIPLE D*CKS)? It 
wouldn't be just to throw him out like that, because he was "elected" 
properly and we wouldn't have anything on him/her. It's too risky to leave 
such a important decision to fate or an other abstract concept for that 
matter. (I like to believe in fate, but not that much.) We managed to 
survive with elective system,even if there have been some mistakes here and 
there (understatement probably), but atleast that way we had a regulating 
systems within (checks and balance for example). This conversation sure did 
quickly turn into a political one ^^ I do enjoy it though :)
comments.author: Loubna Ait

comments.text:
+Loubna Ait The reason I chose random selection is that we want it to be as 
fair as possible. The vote of one evil person, if they end up on the court, 
probably won't be the deciding vote. So they won't have a lot of power. If 
we only use "good" people (whatever that may be defined as), their votes 
might not be in the world's best interests.
comments.author: Alanna R.

comments.text:
I really like that concept, exept of the "randomly-selected" part.I agree 
that it would be better to built a system including the public, but I also 
think that those people should have useful skills. I mean deciding the fate 
of a human is a pretty serious task and i wouldn't want someone having a 
say in it who could potentially become a evil baby (-adult?). God knows 
power can make some people crazy (*carefully glancing into the generial 
direction of an east asian country*). I kind of want to suggest that 
psychology specialists should be in the court, just so that we could 
determine evil babys, but I'm not sure if "evil" or "guilty" for that 
matter, is a psychological or biological issue. Maybe they (the evil babys) 
all have one common trait, that determines whether they turn out normal or 
"evil". And if it's determined, how can you blame them? Would those cases 
still get into the orphanage  or is it for those cases of people who 
deliberatly chose their decision independently? God damn, I don't even 
believe that people can be 100% independant. We had this discuion at 
school, long story short: No one is actually free. You are always 
influenced by exterior factors (IT'S ALL LIES!).
Pleasure writing you again. Have a nice day
comments.author: Loubna Ait

comments.text:
+Loubna Ait The judges would be a few thousand randomly-selected adults 
(different people for each election). Like jury duty, but way more people. 
I don't think Nerdfighteria-wide votes would be quite right, since the EBO 
affects the whole world, not just our small nation. But the law thing is 
the problem. There seems to be no subjective way to decide if something is 
good or bad, it's based only on values. That's where the panel of judges 
comes into play. It's pretty easy to say that they'll decide the world is 
bad if everyone is dead. But it will probably be a harder decision than 
that. So asking the judges will be asking a sample of the general public, 
since that's who this affects. It's pretty easy to say that there will be 
lots of different people from lots of different backgrounds on the panel if 
it's so large. Then the voting should be fair, right?
comments.author: Alanna R.

comments.text:
I like the idea of the "What if-machine". If we get to time travel, then 
this should be easy. Who will be the judges? Who decides who can become a 
judge? Would we habe to start Nerdfighteria-wide votes? I bet the vote 
would be a head-to-head race between Team Green, with John & Hank and 
another Team consiting of the President & Matt Damon. But based on which 
law would the judges make their decisions? They need a constitution as a 
base for their decisions after all. I guess Nerdfighteria would habe to 
build a democratic system around the Evil Baby Orphanage.
comments.author: Loubna Ait

comments.text:
Good point. Argh. No wonder the EBO never became a real thing! I mean, 
there is the issue with time travel, but that's no big deal.

Ok, how about we get a panel of judges, and use the What-If machine to see 
what the world would be like if that person was in the orphanage. Then the 
panel of judges votes on whether the world is a better or worse place 
without that person? Not flawless, but better.
comments.author: Alanna R.

comments.text:

Utilitarianism is the method to go for. Also, who are we to decide whether 
someone belongs to the evil baby orphanage, when their isn't even a 
definition for evil, that everyone agrees to. It's just reaaallly freaking 
hard to find one.

comments.author: TheImmortalGamer

comments.text:
I think that decisions about who should be taken into the evil baby 
orphanage should be based on the direct actions of that individual in their 
adult life and not on any secondary repercussions of their actions. For 
example, Hitler actively made laws to carry out genocide. This is not the 
same thing as, say, a military general blockading a city which results in 
the city's inhabitants' deaths. As John has said before, what is one 
country's 'great' is often another's 'terrible'. This same logic can be 
applied to reverse the titles. In order to avoid morally ambiguous 
repercussions,we should focus on the policy and actions made by that 
person. ﻿

A friend of mine once ran a table top RPG game with us, where the villains

more organized and not crazy leader, leading them to win WWII. The US, as a 
last ditch effort to get as organized as Germany and avoid being invaded, 
instituted it's own fascist dictatorship and a 1984-esque police state. It 
was a compelling thought exercise to say the least.﻿

comments.text:
Also WW2, which probably wouldn't have happened without Hitler, did a lot 
for women's rights in the United States, since they had to get jobs while 
the men were away. The holocaust also brought about a lot of fantastic 
(though tragic) literature like The Diary of Anne Frank and The Boy in the 
Striped Pajamas. And a small portion of TFIOS takes place in a museum that 
wouldn't exist without Hitler, so getting rid of Hitler affects John 
Green's writing. Time travel is complicated.

comments.text:
I think this is all interesting and shit, yet I have a lot of mixed 
feelings, as in I have bad feelings mixed with worse feelings, all about 
this video.
Let's start with the fucking beginning. I was thought that GW was a great 
man. I truly believed that. I'm not saying I have "gut feeling" about this 
shit, but I don't think I was indoctrinated with this idea. When I was a 
kid I was also thought that Jesus was a big deal, but you know what? I 
rejected the idea when I was 4 and I think Jesus was nothing, didn't exist, 
or at best, he was shit. I was and forever be an atheist. Yet, I think the 
first president was a great man. He thought of some things that MOST PEOPLE 
TODAY don't have the brains to think of: separation of church and state, 
the fact that the federal government should be based on a Constitution and 
not traditional national or ethnic customs, he and the other great people 
of his time defined very successfully the modern definition of the word 
"right". Most colonies following the age of colonial empires got their 
independence in the 20th century or 19th century at best. This is fucking 
proof, you retards! I have the fucking proof that GW made my life great and 
I acknowledge that and I am glad I found out who GW was and I think he was 
a great man of history, (along with Napoleon Bonaparte and Otto von 
Bismarck, except GW's successes were peaceful and not military, which is 
even better) and will not be considered wrong hurt just for the sake of 
someone questioning history.
I believe...that we all need to improve our view of the world every second 
of every day. I believe that being smart greatly shadows the advantage of 
being safe in some mentality you failed to improve. I get what is going on. 
The smart people of the 21st century are taking Washington for a little 
questioning: "Was he really how great they say he was?". I applaud that. 
That shows whits. I'm just gonna spoil the answer to your question: yes, he 
was.
P.S. I'm sorry for the "you retards" part. It's just I'm aggressive, that's 
all.﻿
comments.author: bigballsgame

comments.text:
The last question is simply a matter of Power. I don't posses enough of it 
to actively and significantly change the world. Of course I could attempt 
to acquire such power, but that should provide plenty of early warning 
signs if I was in fact a candidate of the evil baby orphanage. As for your 
second question. We can't but should that stop us from doing it? If a 
system is too complex for you to fully understand it, should that stop you 
from trying to improve it? The answer of that is of course dependent on 
wetter or not you consider the system to be operating smoothly enough.﻿

comments.text:
Hitler was born lower middle class and at one point was living on the 
streets for about a year. He joined the army because that was the only job 
he could get. I don't want to go into to much detail, but he was a product 
of a horrible time for German's (post WWI) in which the people (allowed to 
find hope for a prosperous future thanks to the nazi regime) were easily 
persuaded that what the nazis were doing was a good and positive thing. I 
think that if it hadn't been Hitler, the times and hardships would have 
just manufactured another horrible leader and (perhaps not in the same 
fashion) created a people that were comfortable turning a blind eye to 
hatred.

comments.author: Alanna R.

comments.text:
+Erika Schollum Are you saying that authors who have written about altering 
the space-time continuum have some sort of background to support their 
theories on that matter, and we can trust their opinion as evidence? I find 
it hard to believe that going back to change a detail from history will 
derail the world so much. 

If you think about all of the terrible things that HAVE happened in 
history, it's not like they have ruined the world forever. People usually 
find a way to bring justice to evil doers. I think no matter who gets send 
to the evil baby orphanage, the strength of the masses will always ensure 
that the outcome will eventually be okay. It's not going to be like a Meet 
the Robinsons situation where you change one little detail, like whether 
the kid catches the ball in the baseball game, and then it changes history 
dramatically.

Changing a detail like removing Hitler from the 1930s Germany situation 
might change the course of world history, but it doesn't necessarily mean 
that it will be awful or even entirely different. Germans were looking for 
someone to blame for their hardships. History would definitely be 
different. But I don't think it would necessarily be THAT different. And 
even if it was, I don't think it would necessarily be THAT much better or 
worse. Just different.
comments.author: Zachary Cross

comments.text:

comments.text:
I dont think the act itself of eating meat is inherently evil or wrong. 
What is is the process that takes place to get that meat on your plate, 
which includes but is not limited to the way the animals are treated prior 
to being turned into food. I myself am not vegetarian because meat is an 
important part of the human diet, but i only eat it about three times a 
week because of the whole process behind it, which is inhumane, 
inefficient, harmful to the environment, and honestly, just plain gross.
comments.author: Alejandra Ramírez

comments.text:
I've been wondering lately about how WWII wound have played out if you 
removed Hitler, who was hand-picked by the Nazis as a spokesperson and 
became leader of Germany when Hindenburg died. Remove Hitler, and the Nazis 
would've chosen another guy. Maybe one who was a better military leader, or 
humble enough to delegate. Maybe they'd have won the war, if they started 
one at all. Although, millions of Jews probably wouldn't have been 
exterminated, which probably outweighs consequences of war.

comments.text:
It would be a paradox if time flowed in a more or less linear manner. 
However, if you believe in the multiple timelines theory, in which every 
decision ever made splits the timeline into two or more different 
timelines, there would in fact be a timeline where the Evil Baby Orphanage 
had been created and the babies had not grown up to be evil and one where 
it wasn't created and time carried on as if nothing had happened at all. Or 
maybe not. I don't have a firm grasp of space time mechanics.DFTBA
comments.author: Kat Gigliuk

comments.text:
Imagine, for a second, we assume Genghis Khan, the mass-murdering, raping 
brutal military leader, was taken the the EBO. Then his descendants, of 
which there are over 100 million, never exist. What if, say, Gandhi, or 
Douglas Adams, or Mark Twain, or you, John, were descended from Genghis 
Khan. What happens to you?

comments.text:
While George Washington did own slaves, he is also know for how nicely he

will.
